variant.title: 19th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics Proceedings of the Conference
variant.author: 29 June-1 July 1981
variant.note: Published by the Association for Computational Linguistics © 1981, Association for Computational Linguistics Order copies of this and other ACL proceedings from: Donald E. Walker (ACL) Bell Communications Research 445 South Street MRE 2A379 Morristown, NJ 07960-1961, USA
variant.bodyText: This volume is the official record of the proceedings of the 19th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics, held on the campus of Stanford University, from June 29 to July 1, 1981. It contains both the refereed papers presented at the meeting and the position statements of the participants to the two invited panels, the first on the evaluation of natural language interfaces to databases, and the second on parsing. The conference is the result of the efforts of many individuals and institutions, all of whom get my thanks and those of the Association. The program committee consisted of Chip Bruce, Jaime Carbonell, Mitch Marcus, Ellen Prince, Ralph Weischedel, and myself. Jane Robinson and Norman Sondheimer organized the panels. Norman also oversaw the production of these proceedings. Jerry Kaplan handled the local arrangements. Don Walker produced the Call for Papers and the Advanced Program, and was always available to make sure the rest of us didn't forget what to do next. I could never have undertaken to be program chairman without the support I received from my hosts, SRI International and Bolt Beranek and Newman, Inc., while I was on sabbatical from the University of Toronto. My special thanks go to Jane Perry of SRI and Beverly Tobiason of BBN for their secretarial assistance. Financial assistance came from several sources. SRI International produced the Call for Papers and the Advanced Program. Bolt Beranek and Newman provided secretarial support to the program committee. Sperry Univac produced the proceedings. The Department of Computer Science at Stanford provided support for the local arrangements. Most importantly, thanks to all who took the time to write and submit papers. Particular thanks go to those whose submissions could not be accommodated in our limited schedule. Finally, thanks to those who in these days of soaring transportation costs attended the meeting. You make it all worthwhile.

Berwick 7 Chart Parsing and Rule Schemata in PSG Henry Thompson 167 Corepresentational Grammar and Parsing English Comparatives Karen Ryan 13 Performance Comparison of Component Algorithms for Phonemieization of Orthography Jared Bernstein and Larry Nessly 19 PHONY: A Heuristic Phonological Analyzer Lee A. Becker 23 Session I/ Panel: Evaluation of Natural Language Interfaces to Database Systems Norman K. Sondheimer, Chair 29 J. Norwood Crout 31 William C. Mann 33 S. R. Petrick 35 Earl D. Sacerdoti *** Harry Tennant 37 Bozena Henisz Thompson 39 Session III 43 A Grammar and a Lexicon for a Text-Production System Christian Matthiessen 49 Language Production: the Source of the Dictionary David D. McDonald 57 Session /V Analogies in Spontaneous Discourse Rachel Reichman 63 Investigation of Processing Strategies for the Structural Analysis of Arguments Robin Cohen 71 What's Necessary to Hide?: Modeling Action Verbs James F. Allen 77 A Rule-based Conversation Participant Robert E. Frederking 83 Search and Inference Strategies in Pronoun Resolution: An Experimental Study Kate Ehrlich 89 Two Discourse Generators William C. Mann Session V Panel: Perspectives on Parsing Issues Jane J. Robinson, Chair 95 Robert J. Bobrow and Bonnie L. Webber 97 Ralph D. Grishman 101 Ronald M. Kaplan 103 Martin Kay *** Mitchell M. Marcus *** Christopher K. Riesbeck 105 Session VI Presupposition and Implicature in Model-Theoretic Pragmatics Douglas B. Moran 107 Some Computational Aspects of Situation Semantics Jon Barwise 109 A Situation Semantics Approach to the Analysis of Speech Acts David Andreoff Evans 113 Problems in Logical Form Robert C. Moore 117

Hayes 143 A Construction-Specific Approach to Focused Interaction in Flexible Parsing Philip J. Lewis 159 ",* Paper not received at time of publication
